div.p: S. D. I earnestly ask you, lord and brother, to ensure that this letter, addressed to the noble man from Stetten, a citizen of Augsburg, is delivered as quickly and safely as possible; you will greatly oblige me by doing so; I will try to show my gratitude to you if any opportunity presents itself. You have surely heard, even among you, about the severe illness with which I was afflicted by the Lord.

The Lord struck me with the plague in three places; the doctors, otherwise diligent and skilled, despaired of my life. Meanwhile, such great mourning, weeping, and sorrow arose among the entire people that I would never have thought this would happen because of me, a wretched little man. Supplications were instituted in the church.
I immediately felt the vital spirit returning.
In short: I have no doubt that I was granted life through the prayers of the church. I only wish that I may someday meet the expectations of the church.
You, with yours, pray to the Lord for me.

The severe pain in my badly affected right side and head still troubles me in the sixth week; I hope to be restored someday. From my bed, I write this to you, my dearest friend, so that you may know my situation for certain.
Meanwhile, while I lie here gravely ill, my dearest wife, the pride of women, is seized by the same illness and passes away on the ninth day.

You understand how much grief this has caused me; however, since she entrusted her spirit to Christ in true faith among her sons, daughters, sons-in-law, and servants, I know that I have sent her ahead, not lost her.

You will share this with your father, a man I always respect and love. Greet him and the venerable brother ministers, as well as Liner, Rotmund, and Sigismund Zollikofer, and other friends. Farewell excellently.
To the pious, honorable Josua Ke√üler, city scribe in St. Gallen, my dear lord and good friend. St. Gallen.
